description: From Middle English boote, bote (‚Äúshoe‚Äù), from Old French bote (‚Äúa high, thick shoe‚Äù). Of obscure origin, but probably related to Old French bot (‚Äúclub-foot‚Äù), bot (‚Äúfat, short, blunt‚Äù), from Old Frankish *butt, from Proto-Germanic *buttaz, *butaz (‚Äúcut off, short, numb, blunt‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *b ∞ewt-, *b ∞ewd- (‚Äúto strike, push, shock‚Äù); if so, a doublet of butt. Compare Old Norse butt (‚Äústump‚Äù), Low German butt (‚Äúblunt, plump‚Äù), Old English bytt (‚Äúsmall piece of land‚Äù), buttuc (‚Äúend‚Äù). More at buttock and debut.

definitionGroups.group: A heavy shoe that covers part of the leg.

entries.meaning: (sports) A kind of sports shoe worn by players of certain games such as cricket and football.
A blow with the foot; a kick.
(construction) A flexible cover of rubber or plastic, which may be preformed to a particular shape and used to protect a shaft, lever, switch, or opening from dust, dirt, moisture, etc.
(usually preceded by definite article) A torture device used on the feet or legs, such as a Spanish boot.
(US) A parking enforcement device used to immobilize a car until it can be towed or a fine is paid; a wheel clamp.
(aviation) A rubber bladder on the leading edge of an aircraft‚Äôs wing, which is inflated periodically to remove ice buildup; a deicing boot.
(obsolete) A place at the side of a coach, where attendants rode; also, a low outside place before and behind the body of the coach.
(archaic) A place for baggage at either end of an old-fashioned stagecoach.
(US, military, law enforcement, slang) A recently arrived recruit; a rookie.
(Australia, Britain, New Zealand, South Africa, automotive) The luggage storage compartment of a sedan or saloon car.
examples: He heaved the bag and its contents over the lip of the boot and on to the flagstones. When it was out, no longer in that boot but on the ground, and the bag was still intact, he knew the worst was over.

entries.meaning: (informal, with definite article) The act or process of removing or firing someone (dismissing them from a job or other post).
examples: He was useless so he got the boot.

entries.meaning: (Britain, slang) An unattractive person, ugly woman.
examples: old boot

entries.meaning: (slang, ethnic slur) A black person.
(firearms) A hard plastic case for a long firearm, typically moulded to the shape of the gun and intended for use in a vehicle.
(baseball) A bobbled ball.
(botany) The inflated flag leaf sheath of a wheat plant.
(slang) A linear amplifier used with CB radio.
examples: Because of overcrowding, many a CB enthusiast (called an "apple") is strapping an illegal linear amplifier ("boots") on to his transceiver ("ears")  [‚Ä¶]

entries.meaning: (slang, motorsports) A tyre.
(US) A crust end-piece of a loaf of bread.

verbs.description: boot (third-person singular simple present boots, present participle booting, simple past and past participle booted)

entries.meaning: To kick.
examples: I booted the ball toward my teammate.

entries.meaning: To put boots on, especially for riding.
examples: Coated and booted for it.

entries.meaning: (colloquial, Canada, US, usually with it) To step on the accelerator of a vehicle for faster acceleration than usual or to drive faster than usual.
examples: The storm is coming fast! Boot it!
We had to boot it all the way there to get to our flight on time.

entries.meaning: To apply corporal punishment (compare slippering).
(informal) To eject; kick out.
examples: We need to boot those troublemakers as soon as possible.
The senator was booted from the committee for unethical behavior.

entries.meaning: (often with up) To start or restart a computer or other electronic system; to bootstrap.
examples: Boot up the system before 8 a.m. on weekdays.

entries.meaning: (computing, informal) To disconnect forcibly; to eject from an online service, conversation, etc.
examples: As an IRC member with operator status, Swallow was able to manage who was allowed to remain in chat sessions and who got booted off the channel.

entries.meaning: (slang) To vomit.
examples: Sorry, I didn‚Äôt mean to boot all over your couch.

entries.meaning: (MLE, criminal slang) To shoot, to kill by gunfire.

description: From Middle English boote, bote, bot, from Old English b≈çt (‚Äúhelp, relief, advantage, remedy; compensation for an injury or wrong; (peace) offering, recompense, amends, atonement, reformation, penance, repentance‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *b≈çt≈ç (‚Äúatonement, improvement‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *b ∞ed- (‚Äúgood‚Äù). Akin to Old Norse b√≥t (‚Äúbettering, remedy‚Äù) (Danish bod), Gothic êå±êçâêçÑêå∞ (b≈çta), German Bu√üe. Doublet of bote (a borrowing from Middle English).

entries.meaning: (archaic, dialectal) Remedy, amends.
examples: next her Son, our soul's best boot

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Profit, plunder.
(countable, uncountable) That which is given to make an exchange equal, or to make up for the deficiency of value in one of the things exchanged; compensation; recompense.
examples: If mortgaged property is transferred, the amount of the mortgage is part of the boot. If both parties to the transaction transfer mortgages to each other, the party giving up the larger debt treats the excess as taxable boot.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Profit; gain; advantage; use.
(obsolete) Repair work; the act of fixing structures or buildings. [to mid-17th c.]
(obsolete) A medicinal cure or remedy. [to mid-16th c.]

verbs.description: boot (third-person singular simple present boots, present participle booting, simple past and past participle booted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To avail, benefit, profit.
examples: What booteth it to others that we wish them well, and do nothing for them?

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To benefit, to enrich; to give in addition.
(computing) The act or process of bootstrapping; the starting or re-starting of a computing device.
examples: It took three boots, but I finally got the application installed.

verbs.description: boot (third-person singular simple present boots, present participle booting, simple past and past participle booted)

entries.meaning: (computing) To bootstrap; to start a system, e.g. a computer, by invoking its boot process or bootstrap.
examples: Synonyms: bootstrap, boot up, start
Antonyms: shut down, stop, turn off
When arriving at the office, the first thing I do is boot my machine.

description: From bootleg (‚Äúto make or sell illegally‚Äù), by shortening.

entries.meaning: (informal) A bootleg recording.
examples: I am looking to trade Iron Maiden boots. I have many Iron Maiden bootlegs. I have lots of Metallica. I trade CDR's, tapes and videos.
